dyad.stats.period.trunclognorm#

dyad.stats.period.trunclognorm = <dyad.stats.period.trunclognorm_gen object>#

A truncated lognormal random variable

As an instance of the rv_continuous class, dyad.stats.period.trunclognorm object inherits from it a collection of generic methods (see below for the full list), and completes them with details specific for this particular distribution.

Methods

rvs(s, a, b, loc=0, scale=1, size=1, random_state=None)

Random variates.

pdf(x, s, a, b, loc=0, scale=1)

Probability density function.

logpdf(x, s, a, b, loc=0, scale=1)

Log of the probability density function.

cdf(x, s, a, b, loc=0, scale=1)

Cumulative distribution function.

logcdf(x, s, a, b, loc=0, scale=1)

Log of the cumulative distribution function.

sf(x, s, a, b, loc=0, scale=1)

Survival function (also defined as 1 - cdf, but sf is sometimes more accurate).

logsf(x, s, a, b, loc=0, scale=1)

Log of the survival function.

ppf(q, s, a, b, loc=0, scale=1)

Percent point function (inverse of cdf — percentiles).

isf(q, s, a, b, loc=0, scale=1)

Inverse survival function (inverse of sf).

moment(order, s, a, b, loc=0, scale=1)

Non-central moment of the specified order.

stats(s, a, b, loc=0, scale=1, moments=’mv’)

Mean(‘m’), variance(‘v’), skew(‘s’), and/or kurtosis(‘k’).

entropy(s, a, b, loc=0, scale=1)

(Differential) entropy of the RV.

fit(data)

Parameter estimates for generic data. See scipy.stats.rv_continuous.fit for detailed documentation of the keyword arguments.

expect(func, args=(s, a, b), loc=0, scale=1, lb=None, ub=None, conditional=False, **kwds)

Expected value of a function (of one argument) with respect to the distribution.

median(s, a, b, loc=0, scale=1)

Median of the distribution.

mean(s, a, b, loc=0, scale=1)

Mean of the distribution.

var(s, a, b, loc=0, scale=1)

Variance of the distribution.

std(s, a, b, loc=0, scale=1)

Standard deviation of the distribution.

interval(confidence, s, a, b, loc=0, scale=1)

Confidence interval with equal areas around the median.

Notes

The probability density function for trunclognorm is:

\[f_{P}(p, a, b, s) = \dfrac{\exp\left(-\dfrac{\log(p)^{2}}{2s^{2}}\right)} {\sqrt{2\pi}sx\left(\operatorname{erf}\left(\dfrac{\log(b)}{s}\right) - \operatorname{erf}\left(\dfrac{\log(a)}{s}\right)\right)}\]

where \(p \in (a, b)\), \(a, b \in (0, \infty)\), and \(s \in (0, \infty)\).

The probability density function trunclognorm takes a, b, and s as shape parameters for $a$, $b$, and $s$.

Notice that the truncation values, $a$ and $b$, are defined in standardized form:

\[a = (u_{\mathrm{l}} - \mathrm{loc})/\mathrm{scale}, b = (u_{\mathrm{r}} - \mathrm{loc})/\mathrm{scale}\]

where \(u_{\mathrm{l}}\) and \(u_{\text{r}}\) are the specific left and right truncation values, respectively. In other words, the support of the distribution becomes \((a*\mathrm{scale} + \mathrm{loc}) < x <= (b*\mathrm{scale} + \mathrm{loc})\) when \(\mathrm{loc}\) and/or \(\mathrm{scale}\) are provided.

Suppose a normally distributed random variable X has mean mu and standard deviation sigma. Then Y = exp(X) is lognormally distributed with s = sigma and scale = exp(mu). To change the base of the lognormal distribution from e to base b multiply mu and sigma by ln(b).

The probability density above is defined in the “standardized” form. To shift and/or scale the distribution use the loc and scale parameters. Specifically, period.trunclognorm.pdf(x, s, a, b, loc, scale) is identically equivalent to dyad.stats.period.trunclognorm.pdf(y, s, a, b) / scale with y = (x - loc) / scale. Note that shifting the location of a distribution does not make it a “noncentral” distribution; noncentral generalizations of some distributions are available in separate classes.

References

'Truncated Normal Distribution'. 2024. In /Wikipedia/. https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Truncated_normal_distribution&oldid=1217498083.

Examples

>>> import numpy as np
>>> import dyad
>>> import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
>>> fig, ax = plt.subplots(1, 1)

Calculate the first four moments:

>>> s, a, b = (5.3, 1.58e-07, 15800000.0, 63100.0)
>>> mean, var, skew, kurt = dyad.stats.period.trunclognorm.stats(s, a, b, moments='mvsk')

Display the probability density function (pdf):

>>> x = np.linspace(dyad.stats.period.trunclognorm.ppf(0.01, s, a, b),
...                 dyad.stats.period.trunclognorm.ppf(0.99, s, a, b), 100)
>>> ax.plot(x, dyad.stats.period.trunclognorm.pdf(x, s, a, b),
...        'r-', lw=5, alpha=0.6, label='dyad.stats.period.trunclognorm pdf')

Alternatively, the distribution object can be called (as a function) to fix the shape, location and scale parameters. This returns a “frozen” RV object holding the given parameters fixed.

Freeze the distribution and display the frozen pdf:

>>> rv = dyad.stats.period.trunclognorm(s, a, b)
>>> ax.plot(x, rv.pdf(x), 'k-', lw=2, label='frozen pdf')

Check accuracy of cdf and ppf:

>>> vals = dyad.stats.period.trunclognorm.ppf([0.001, 0.5, 0.999], s, a, b)
>>> np.allclose([0.001, 0.5, 0.999], dyad.stats.period.trunclognorm.cdf(vals, s, a, b))
True

Generate random numbers:

>>> r = dyad.stats.period.trunclognorm.rvs(s, a, b, size=1000)

And compare the histogram:

>>> ax.hist(r, density=True, bins='auto', histtype='stepfilled', alpha=0.2)
>>> ax.set_xlim([x[0], x[-1]])
>>> ax.legend(loc='best', frameon=False)
>>> plt.show()
